This enables the team to adapt and adjust without compromising the overall quality of the deliverables.

questions.question_text: How does PRINCE2 Agile describe Scrum?

choices.B: Scrum is agile and agile is Scrum
choices.C: Scrum is the most well-known agile framework
choices.D: Scrum is a project management framework

discussion.content:
D. Scrum is a project management framework.

PRINCE2 Agile describes Scrum as a project management framework that is commonly used in Agile environments. Scrum is a framework that is used to manage and deliver complex products by following an iterative approach. It is based on the principles of transparency, inspection, and adaptation and is commonly used in software development projects.

Option A (Scrum is an IT method) is not entirely accurate, as Scrum can be used in any industry or sector, not just IT.

Option B (Scrum is agile and agile is Scrum) is not correct, as Scrum is just one of the Agile frameworks and methodologies available, and Agile encompasses a broader range of methodologies and frameworks beyond Scrum.

Option C (Scrum is the most well-known agile framework) is not entirely accurate. While Scrum is one of the most well-known Agile frameworks, there are other Agile frameworks and methodologies that are also widely used, such as Kanban, Lean, and XP (Extreme Programming).

10.2.1 Common agile viewpoints of roles
I. The Scrum master: A common role in agile is that of the Scrum master, who provides servant leadership (see section 10.5.1). The Scrum master facilitates and coaches the Scrum process while removing impediments identified by the team working at the delivery level. It could be said that there is no equivalent role in PRINCE2. The team manager is the most obvious candidate, but in Scrum and in many agile belief systems the team does not need to be ‘managed’ per se; it needs to be ‘led and coached’. When using agile in a PRINCE2 environment there will need to be a team manager or equivalent who is accountable to the project manager for the delivery of a team’s products, but this will need to be handled appropriately (see section 10.4.1).
